unnormalised: Energy & Utilities: Load Shedding Woes Continue Across Northern India
normalised: energy and utilities: load shedding woes continue across northern india

unnormalised: NEW DELHI, July 26th - Unscheduled power outages, locally termed "load shedding," persist across several states in northern India, disrupting daily life and impacting businesses. Areas in Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, and even parts of Delhi are experiencing blackouts lasting for several hours daily, exacerbating the already challenging summer heat.
normalised: new delhi, july twenty sixth - unscheduled power outages, locally termed "load shedding," persist across several states in northern india, disrupting daily life and impacting businesses. areas in uttar pradesh, rajasthan, and even parts of delhi are experiencing blackouts lasting for several hours daily, exacerbating the already challenging summer heat.

unnormalised: Dr. Sharma, a spokesperson for the Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL), cited "unforeseen technical glitches" and increased demand due to excessive air conditioner use as contributing factors. He assured the public that engineers are working tirelessly to rectify the situation.
normalised: doctor sharma, a spokesperson for the U P P C L, cited "unforeseen technical glitches" and increased demand due to excessive air conditioner use as contributing factors. he assured the public that engineers are working tirelessly to rectify the situation.

unnormalised: The Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) estimates that these power disruptions are costing businesses Rs. 500 crores daily in lost productivity. Small businesses, particularly those operating out of smaller spaces (around 500 sq ft), are disproportionately affected.
normalised: the confederation of indian industry (C I I) estimates that these power disruptions are costing businesses rupees five hundred crore daily in lost productivity. small businesses, particularly those operating out of smaller spaces (around five hundred square feet), are disproportionately affected.

unnormalised: Residents are expressing frustration, drawing parallels to the power crises faced in the 1990s. Many are relying on inverters and generators, further straining the power grid. The situation is particularly worrying for students preparing for competitive exams. UPPCL anticipates the situation will improve by the end of next week with the commissioning of new transmission lines.
normalised: residents are expressing frustration, drawing parallels to the power crises faced in the nineteen nineties. many are relying on inverters and generators, further straining the power grid. the situation is particularly worrying for students preparing for competitive exams. U P P C L anticipates the situation will improve by the end of next week with the commissioning of new transmission lines.
